column4: hi.  if i were logged in as root, for whatever reason, and i want to open a program like my browser not as root, how would I go about this?
is there a command that is the upposite of sudo or gksu?

hi, i just tried when logged in as root, sudo nautilus, gksudo nautilus, and gksu nautilus and all three times it still opened as root...  any ideas?  i am trying, when logged in as root, to be able to run programs not as root
you need to run "gksudo -u some_username nautilus"
ah yes, nautilus is both the background AND a filemanager. use "gksudo -u s nautilus --no-desktop"
did you try it with --no-desktop added?
in a terminal type "gksu some_user nautilus --no-desktop" and pastebin the output if it doesn't work
looks like root is protecting it's X session (good thing). I recommend not running a GUI as root anyways. *Why* are you logging in as root in the first place?
when i use backtrack i need to be logged in as root
when you use the backtrack software, or the distribution?
backtrack is not an official ubuntu derivative, please contact the backtrack developers directly for assistance with their distrobution
if backtrack requires you to be logged in as root (something ubuntu does NOT do), that is an issue you need to bring up with *them*
I don't think backbox IS a Canonical endorsed distro at all
